titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the William A. Eardeley New York State law reports manuscript 1973.263
titlestmt.author: Dee Bowers

did.unittitle: William A. Eardeley New York State law reports manuscript
did.abstract: Extracts from New York State law reports transcribed by genealogist William A. Eardeley. The records date from 1630-1844, and they were transcribed circa 1928-1932.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Source and date of acquisition unknown. The collection was formally accessioned in 1973.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This small collection is housed in a single folder in its original order.

bioghist.head: Biographical note
bioghist.p: William Applebie Daniel Eardeley (1870â€“1935) was a prolific genealogist hailing from Brooklyn, NY. Over the course of his career he amassed an extensive collection of genealogical information concerning families from all parts of the state of New York. The Center for Brooklyn History has made Eardeley's collection available to researchers on microfilm.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: William A. Eardeley New York State law reports manuscript, 1973.263, Box and Folder number; Brooklyn Public Library, Center for Brooklyn History.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: This collection was rehoused and the finding aid created by Dee Bowers in 2024.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Materials
relatedmaterial.p: Eardeley NYS Wills Names Index & Eardeley Manuscripts on Microfilm - available in person at Center for Brooklyn History and other repositories.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Extracts from New York State law reports transcribed by genealogist William A. Eardeley. The records date from 1630-1844, and they were transcribed circa 1928-1932. Includes: notes on NYS Court of Probates; types of court records by year for NYS counties, 1630-1892; transcripts of court minutes from many counties, incl. Supreme Court, 1793-1844; wills, pleas, and estate information.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: While many items at the Center for Brooklyn History are unrestricted, we do not own reproduction rights to all materials. Be aware of the several kinds of rights that might apply: copyright, licensing and trademarks. The researcher assumes all responsibility for copyright questions.
